edu.frontrange.csc240.a3.example1

Class Pi_5_20

  • Object
    • edu.frontrange.csc240.a3.example1.Pi_5_20

  • public class Pi_5_20
extends Object
    Prints an estimate of the value of the constant pi obtained by a series expansion to the number of terms given by the user.

    This implementation illustrates a separation of concerns, by having the interaction with the user in one method, and the computation of the needed value in its own method.

    The series uses is based on the formula given in the text book in Exercise 5.20. This series converges EXTREMELY slowly, so even allowing the number of terms to be entered as a long value, with many billions or even trillions of terms, the value of pi is still not correct to 15 decimal places. This is to illustrate that not all series are suitable for computational use, even if mathematically correct and accurate.

    Version:
    2016-08-22, CSC-240 Assignment 3, Sample
    Author:
    Dr. Bruce K. Haddon, Instructor

    • Method Detail

      • pi_estimate

        public double pi_estimate(long numberOfTerms)
        Compute the value of pi_estimate, the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter, using the so-called Gregory series, as accurately as possible to the given number of terms, which is assumed (precondition) to be greater than or equal to 1.

        Each term in the series is only a little smaller than the one before. But the terms do get smaller, so there is no danger of overflow in the addition. However, the value 2.0 * n is computed, which, for very large values of n, could overflow and produce an incorrect result.

        Parameters:
        numberOfTerms - the number of terms of the Gregory series to be used (greater than or equal to 1)
        Returns:
        the the value of pi_estimate, computed as accurately as possible with the given number of terms

      • run

        public void run()
        Perform the tasks of the Pi class. i.e., compute and estimate of the value of the constant π to the input number of terms, and print the results.

        The run method handles the details of the interaction with the user, asking again for input if an unusable value is obtained. Once the number of terms has been successfully obtained, this method delegates to the method that actually performs the computation. The estimate obtained is printed, and a value obtained from the JDK Math class is also printed for comparison.

      • main

        public static void main(String... args)
        Main entry point.

        Execute: 

        java edu.frontrange.csc240.a3.example1.Pi_5_20
        Parameters:
        args - not used.
